thread.title: Closing Essendon makes no sense: experts - Yahoo7
thread.title_full: Closing Essendon makes no sense: experts - Yahoo7

author: Aap
title: Closing Essendon makes no sense: experts - Yahoo7
text:
Share Closing Essendon makes no sense: experts - Yahoo7 Just hours after a crash that claimed the lives of five people, there's already speculation about the future of Essendon Airport but experts say it doesn't make any sense to shut down the airfield permanently. Close Crash raises questions over future of Essendon Airport UP NEXT VIDEO Crash raises questions over future of airstrip, close to homes, businesses. 7News Crash raises questions over future of Essendon Airport 
A light plane crashed into the Essendon DFO, narrowly missing a major motorway, shortly before 9am on Tuesday. 
The crash renewed speculation over whether the airport, surrounded by homes, a retail outlet and freeway, should remain open. Emergency crews at the Essendon scene. Picture: AAP 
"These developments do pose an enormous safety risk to the flying public" Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association spokesperson Ben Morgan said. 
As well as passenger flights, freight and emergency services aircraft use Essendon airport, 16km north of Melbourne. Close Five killed in Melbourne plane tragedy UP NEXT VIDEO Five dead in horror plane crash Five killed in Melbourne plane tragedy 
Calls to close it started after a plane crashed into a house killing six members of one family in 1978 and was renewed in the 1990s when a chartered plane crashed into five houses, injuring passengers and residents. 
On the other side of Melbourne, a trainee pilot died in 2008 when his plane crashed near a school and homes in Cheltenham after taking off at Moorabin airport in the southeastern suburbs, while another pilot flying from the airport was killed in 2014 after crashing into a house. A wheel from the plane landed on the Tullamarine Freeway. Picture: AAP 
University of NSW school of aviation head Jason Middleton, who used to be a charter pilot between Moorabin and King Island, said the suburban airports were originally surrounded by fields until the urban sprawl crept up. 
Prof Middleton says extensive safety measures were in place and airports need to be in convenient locations. 
"(Crashes are) such rare events and with all the safety systems in place, you're not going to simply move a $5 billion airport just in case there's an accident that that might happen once in 50 or 100 years," Prof Middleton told AAP. 
Senior aviation lecturer at Central Queensland University, Ronald Bishop told AAP there would be logistical issues with making all aircraft use a large airport such Tullamarine. 
Both Premier Daniel Andrews and Essendon MP Danny Pearson refused to be drawn into the speculation over the airstrip's future when asked on Tuesday. 
"Essendon fields plays a really important role in our community in terms of running the air ambulance out there and the police airwing," Mr Pearson said. 
"I think rather than offering opinions â€¦ I think the best thing to do here is get the facts of the matter," Mr Andrews added. 
A full investigation is now underway into the cause of the plane tragedy. Close Horror crash captured by witnesses UP NEXT
